1.verse: The Parable of the Fig Tree - At that moment some people came up and told them the news. Some Galileans had been in the Temple, and Pilate had mixed their blood with that of the sacrifices.

2.verse: ‘Do you suppose’, said Jesus, ‘that those Galileans suffered such things because they were greater sinners than all other Galileans?

3.verse: No, let me tell you! Unless you repent, you will all be destroyed in the same way.

4.verse: ‘And what about those eighteen who were killed when the tower in Siloam collapsed on top of them? Do you imagine they were more blameworthy than everyone else who lives in Jerusalem?

5.verse: No, let me tell you! Unless you repent, you will all be destroyed in the same way.’

6.verse: He told them this parable. ‘Once upon a time there was a man who had a fig tree in his vineyard. He came to it looking for fruit, and didn’t find any.

7.verse: So he said to the gardener, “Look here! I’ve been coming to this fig tree for three years hoping to find some fruit, and I haven’t found any! Cut it down! Why should it use up the soil?”

8.verse: ‘ “I tell you what, Master,” replied the gardener; “let it alone for just this one year more. I’ll dig all round it and put on some manure.

9.verse: Then, if it fruits next year, well and good; and if not, you can cut it down.” ’

10.verse: Jesus Heals a Crippled Woman on the Sabbath - One sabbath, Jesus was teaching in one of the synagogues.

11.verse: There was a woman there who had had a spirit of weakness for eighteen years. She was bent double, and couldn’t stand fully upright.

12.verse: Jesus saw her and called to her.

13.verse: ‘Woman,’ he said, laying his hands on her, ‘you are freed from your affliction.’ And at once she stood upright, and praised God.

14.verse: The synagogue president was angry that Jesus had healed on the sabbath. ‘Look here,’ he said to the crowd, ‘there are six days for people to work! Come on one of those days and be healed, not on the sabbath day!’

15.verse: ‘You bunch of hypocrites!’ replied Jesus. ‘You would all be quite happy to untie an ox or a donkey from its stall on the sabbath day and lead it out for a drink!

16.verse: And isn’t it right that this daughter of Abraham, tied up by the satan for these eighteen years, should be untied from her chains on the sabbath day?’

17.verse: At that, all the people who had been opposing him were ashamed. The whole crowd was overjoyed at all the splendid things he was doing.

18.verse: So Jesus said, ‘What is God’s kingdom like? What shall we compare it with?

19.verse: It’s like a mustard seed that someone took and placed in his garden. It grew, and became a tree, and the birds of the sky made nests in its branches.’

20.verse: And again he said, ‘What shall we say God’s kingdom is like?

21.verse: It’s like leaven that a woman took and hid in three measures of flour, until the whole thing was leavened.’

22.verse: Entering through the Narrow Door - Jesus went through the towns and villages, teaching as he went, making his way towards Jerusalem.

23.verse: ‘Master,’ somebody said to him, ‘will there be only a few that are saved?’

24.verse: ‘Struggle hard’, Jesus replied, ‘to get in by the narrow gate. Let me tell you: many will try to get in and won’t be able to.

25.verse: When the householder gets up and shuts the door – at that moment you will begin to stand outside and knock at the door and say, “Master, open the door for us.” Then he will say in response, “I don’t know where you’ve come from.”

26.verse: Then you will begin to say, “We ate with you and drank with you, and you taught in our streets!”

27.verse: And he will say to you, “I don’t know where you people are from. Be off with you, you wicked lot.”

28.verse: ‘That’s where you’ll find weeping and gnashing of teeth: when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in God’s kingdom, and you yourselves thrown out.

29.verse: People will come from East and West, from North and South, and sit down to feast in God’s kingdom.

30.verse: And, listen to this: some who are last will be first, and some of the first will be last.’

31.verse: Jesus Grieves over Jerusalem - Just then some Pharisees came up and spoke to Jesus. ‘Get away from here,’ they said, ‘because Herod wants to kill you.’

32.verse: ‘Go and tell that fox,’ replied Jesus, ‘ “Look here: I’m casting out demons today and tomorrow, and completing my healings. I’ll be finished by the third day.

33.verse: But I have to continue my travels today, tomorrow and the day after that! It couldn’t happen that a prophet would perish except in Jerusalem.”

34.verse: ‘Jerusalem, Jerusalem! You kill the prophets, and stone the people sent to you! How many times did I want to collect your children, like a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you would have none of it!

35.verse: Look, your house has been abandoned. Let me tell you this: you will never see me until you are prepared to say, “A blessing upon you! Welcome in the name of the Lord!” ’

1.verse: Jesus and the Pharisee - One sabbath, Jesus went to a meal in the house of a leading Pharisee. They were keeping a close eye on him.

2.verse: There was a man there in front of Jesus who suffered from dropsy.

3.verse: So Jesus asked the lawyers and Pharisees, ‘Is it lawful to heal on the sabbath or not?’

4.verse: They remained silent. He took the man, healed him, and dismissed him.

5.verse: Then he said to them, ‘Suppose one of you has a son – or an ox! – that falls into a well. Are you going to tell me you won’t pull him out straight away on the sabbath day?’

6.verse: They had no answer for that.

7.verse: He noticed how the guests chose the best seats, and told them this parable.

8.verse: ‘When someone invites you to a wedding feast,’ he said, ‘don’t go and sit in the best seat, in case some other guest more important is invited,

9.verse: and the person who invited you both comes and says to you, “Please move down for this man,” and you will go to the end of the line covered with embarrassment.

10.verse: Instead, when someone invites you, go and sit down at the lowest place. Then, when your host arrives, he will say to you, “My dear fellow! Come on higher up!” Then all your fellow guests will show you respect.

11.verse: All who push themselves forward, you see, will be humbled, and all who humble themselves will be honoured.’

12.verse: The Parable of the Great Banquet - He then turned to his host. ‘When you give a lunch or a supper,’ he said, ‘don’t invite your friends or your family or relatives, or your rich neighbours. They might ask you back again, and you’d be repaid.

13.verse: When you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame and the blind.

14.verse: God will bless you, because they have no way to repay you! You will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous.’

15.verse: One of the guests heard this, and commented, ‘A blessing on those who eat food in God’s kingdom!’

16.verse: Jesus said, ‘Once a man made a great dinner, and invited lots of guests.

17.verse: When the time for the meal arrived, he sent his servant to say to the guests, “Come now – everything’s ready!”

18.verse: But the whole pack of them began to make excuses. The first said, “I’ve just bought a field, and I really have to go and see it. Please accept my apologies.”

19.verse: Another one said, “I’ve just bought five yoke of oxen, and I’ve got to go and test them out – please accept my apologies.”

20.verse: And another one said, “I’ve just got married, so naturally I can’t come.”

21.verse: So the servant went back and told his master all this. The householder was cross, and said to his servant, “Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the town and bring in here the poor, the crippled, the lame and the blind.”

22.verse: “All right, Master,” said the servant, “I’ve done that – but there’s still room.”

23.verse: “Well then,” said the master to the servant, “go out into the roads and hedgerows and make them come in, so that my house may be full!

24.verse: Let me tell you this: none of those people who were invited will get to taste my dinner.” ’

25.verse: The Cost of Discipleship - A large crowd was gathering around him. Jesus turned to face them.

26.verse: ‘If any of you come to me,’ he said to them, ‘and don’t hate your father and your mother, your wife and your children, your brothers and your sisters – yes, and even your own life! – you can’t be my disciple.

27.verse: If you don’t pick up your own cross and come after me, you can’t be my disciple.

28.verse: ‘Don’t you see? Supposing one of you wants to build a tower; what will you do? You will first of all sit down and work out how much it will cost, to see whether you have enough to finish it.

29.verse: Otherwise, when you’ve laid the foundation and then can’t finish it, everyone who sees it will begin to make fun of you.

30.verse: “Here’s a fellow”, they’ll say, “who began to build but couldn’t finish!”

31.verse: ‘Or think of a king, on the way to fight a war against another king. What will he do? He will first sit down and discuss with his advisers whether, with ten thousand troops, he is going to be a match for the other side who are coming with twenty thousand!

32.verse: If they decide he isn’t, he will send a delegation, while the other one is still a long way away, and sue for peace.

33.verse: ‘In the same way, none of you can be my disciple unless you give up all your possessions.

34.verse: ‘Salt is good; but if even the salt loses its savour, how can it be made salty again?

35.verse: It’s no good for soil and no good for manure. People throw it away. If you have ears, then listen!’

1.verse: The Parables of the Lost Sheep and the Lost Coin - All the tax-collectors and sinners were coming close to listen to Jesus.

2.verse: The Pharisees and the legal experts were grumbling. ‘This fellow welcomes sinners!’ they said. ‘He even eats with them!’

3.verse: So Jesus told them this parable.

4.verse: ‘Supposing one of you has a hundred sheep,’ he said, ‘and you lose one of them. What will you do? Why, you’ll leave the ninety-nine out in the countryside, and you’ll go off looking for the lost one until you find it!

5.verse: And when you find it, you’ll be so happy – you’ll put it on your shoulders

6.verse: and come home, and you’ll call your friends and neighbours in. “Come and have a party!” you’ll say. “Celebrate with me! I’ve found my lost sheep!”

7.verse: ‘Well, let me tell you: that’s how glad they will be in heaven over one sinner who repents – more than over ninety-nine righteous people who don’t need repentance.

8.verse: ‘Or supposing a woman has ten drachmas and loses one of them. What will she do? Why, she’ll light a lamp, and sweep the house, and hunt carefully until she finds it!

9.verse: And when she finds it she’ll call her friends and neighbours in. “Come and have a party!” she’ll say. “Celebrate with me! I’ve found my lost coin!”

10.verse: ‘Well, let me tell you: that’s how glad God’s angels feel when a single sinner repents.’

11.verse: The Parable of the Prodigal: The Father and the Younger Son - Jesus went on: ‘Once there was a man who had two sons.

12.verse: The younger son said to the father, “Father, give me my share in the property.” So he divided up his livelihood between them.

13.verse: Not many days later the younger son turned his share into cash, and set off for a country far away, where he spent his share in having a riotous good time.

14.verse: ‘When he had spent it all, a severe famine came on that country, and he found himself destitute.

15.verse: So he went and attached himself to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him into the fields to feed his pigs.

16.verse: He longed to satisfy his hunger with the pods that the pigs were eating, and nobody gave him anything.

17.verse: ‘He came to his senses. “Just think!” he said to himself. “There are all my father’s hired hands with plenty to eat – and here am I, starving to death!

18.verse: I shall get up and go to my father, and I’ll say to him: ‘Father; I have sinned against heaven and before you;

19.verse: I don’t deserve to be called your son any longer. Make me like one of your hired hands.’ ”

20.verse: And he got up and went to his father. ‘While he was still a long way off, his father saw him and his heart was stirred with love and pity. He ran to him, hugged him tight, and kissed him.

21.verse: “Father,” the son began, “I have sinned against heaven and before you; I don’t deserve to be called your son any longer.”

22.verse: But the father said to his servants, “Hurry! Bring the best clothes and put them on him! Put a ring on his hand, and shoes on his feet!

23.verse: And bring the calf that we’ve fattened up, kill it, and let’s eat and have a party!

24.verse: This son of mine was dead, and is alive again! He was lost, and now he’s found!” And they began to celebrate.’

25.verse: The Parable of the Prodigal: The Father and the Older Son - ‘The older son was out in the fields. When he came home, and got near to the house, he heard music and dancing.

26.verse: He called one of the servants and asked what was going on.

27.verse: ‘ “Your brother’s come home!” he said. “And your father has thrown a great party – he’s killed the fattened calf! – because he’s got him back safe and well!”

28.verse: ‘He flew into a rage, and wouldn’t go in. ‘Then his father came out and pleaded with him.

29.verse: “Look here!” he said to his father, “I’ve been slaving for you all these years! I’ve never disobeyed a single commandment of yours. And you never even gave me a young goat so I could have a party with my friends.

30.verse: But when this son of yours comes home, once he’s finished gobbling up your livelihood with his whores, you kill the fattened calf for him!”

31.verse: ‘ “My son,” he replied, “you’re always with me. Everything I have belongs to you.

32.verse: But we had to celebrate and be happy! This brother of yours was dead and is alive again! He was lost, and now he’s found!” ’

1.verse: The Parable of the Shrewd Manager - Jesus said to his disciples, ‘Once there was a rich man who had a steward, and charges were laid against him that he was squandering his property.

2.verse: So he called him and said to him, “What’s all this I hear about you? Present an account of your stewardship; I’m not going to have you as my steward any more!”

3.verse: ‘At this, the steward said to himself, “What shall I do? My master is taking away my stewardship from me! I can’t do manual work, and I’d be ashamed to beg ...

4.verse: ‘ “I have an idea what to do! – so that people will welcome me into their households when I am fired from being steward.”

5.verse: ‘So he called his master’s debtors to him, one by one. “How much”, he asked the first, “do you owe my master?”

6.verse: ‘ “A hundred measures of olive oil,” he replied. ‘ “Take your bill,” he said to him, “sit down quickly, and make it fifty.”

7.verse: ‘To another he said, “And how much do you owe?” ‘ “A hundred measures of wheat,” he replied. ‘ “Take your bill,” he said, “and make it eighty.”

8.verse: ‘And the master praised the dishonest steward because he had acted wisely. The children of this world, you see, are wiser than the children of light when it comes to dealing with their own generation.

9.verse: ‘So let me tell you this: use that dishonest stuff called money to make yourselves friends! Then, when it gives out, they will welcome you into homes that will last.’

10.verse: Teachings on Stewardship - ‘Someone who is faithful in a small matter’, Jesus continued, ‘will also be faithful in a large one. Someone who is dishonest in a small matter will also be dishonest in a large one.

11.verse: If you haven’t been faithful with that wicked thing called money, who is going to entrust you with true wealth?

12.verse: And if you haven’t been faithful in looking after what belongs to someone else, who is going to give you what is your own?

13.verse: ‘Nobody can serve two masters. You will end up hating one and loving the other, or going along with the first and despising the other. You can’t serve God and money.’

14.verse: The Pharisees, who loved money, heard all this, and mocked Jesus.

15.verse: So he said to them, ‘You people let everyone else know that you’re in the right – but God knows your hearts. What people call honourable, God calls abominable!

16.verse: ‘The law and the prophets lasted until John. From now on, God’s kingdom is announced, and everyone is trying to attack it.

17.verse: But it’s easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one dot of an “i” to drop out of the law.

18.verse: ‘Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and a person who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.’

19.verse: The Parable of the Rich Man and Lazarus - ‘There was once a rich man,’ said Jesus, ‘who was dressed in purple and fine linen, and feasted in splendour every day.

20.verse: A poor man named Lazarus, who was covered with sores, lay outside his gate.

21.verse: He longed to feed himself with the scraps that fell from the rich man’s table. Even the dogs came and licked his sores.

22.verse: ‘In due course the poor man died, and was carried by the angels into Abraham’s bosom. The rich man also died, and was buried.

23.verse: As he was being tormented in Hades, he looked up and saw Abraham far away, and Lazarus in his bosom.

24.verse: ‘ “Father Abraham!” he called out. “Have pity on me! Send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue! I’m in agony in this fire!”

25.verse: ‘ “My child,” replied Abraham, “remember that in your life you received good things, and in the same way Lazarus received evil. Now he is comforted here, and you are tormented.

26.verse: Besides that, there is a great chasm standing between us. People who want to cross over from here to you can’t do so, nor can anyone get across from the far side to us.”

27.verse: ‘ “Please, then, father,” he said, “send him to my father’s house.

28.verse: I’ve got five brothers. Let him tell them about it, so that they don’t come into this torture-chamber.”

29.verse: ‘ “They’ve got Moses and the prophets,” replied Abraham. “Let them listen to them.”

30.verse: ‘ “No, father Abraham,” he replied, “but if someone went to them from the dead, they would repent!”

31.verse: ‘ “If they don’t listen to Moses and the prophets,” came the reply, “neither would they be convinced, even if someone rose from the dead.” ’

1.verse: Forgiveness, Faith and Obedience - Jesus said to his disciples, ‘There are bound to be things that trip people up; but woe betide the person who brings them about!

2.verse: It would be better to have a millstone hung around your neck, and be thrown into the sea, than to trip up one of these little ones.

3.verse: So watch out for yourselves. ‘If your brother sins against you, rebuke him; and if he apologizes, forgive him.

4.verse: Even if he sins against you seven times, and turns round seven times and says “sorry” to you, you must forgive him.’

5.verse: The apostles said to the master, ‘Give us greater faith!’

6.verse: ‘If you had faith’, replied the master, ‘as a grain of mustard seed, you would say to this mulberry tree, “Be uprooted and be planted in the sea”, and it would obey you.

7.verse: ‘Supposing one of you has a slave ploughing or keeping sheep out in the field. When he comes in, what will you say? “Come here at once, and sit down for a meal?”

8.verse: No; you will be far more likely to say, “Get something ready for me to eat! Get properly dressed, and wait on me while I eat and drink! After that you can have something to eat and drink yourself.”

9.verse: Will you thank the slave because he did what you told him?

10.verse: ‘That’s how it is with you. When you’ve done everything you’re told, say this: “We’re just ordinary slaves. All we’ve done is what we we were supposed to do.” ’

11.verse: Ten Men Healed - As Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem, he passed along the borderlands between Samaria and Galilee.

12.verse: As he was going into one particular village he was met by ten men with virulent skin diseases who stayed at some distance from him.

13.verse: ‘Jesus, Master!’ they called out loudly. ‘Have pity on us!’

14.verse: When Jesus saw them he said to them, ‘Go and show yourselves to the priests.’ And as they went, they were healed.

15.verse: One of them, seeing that he had been healed, turned back and gave glory to God at the top of his voice.

16.verse: He fell on his face in front of Jesus’ feet and thanked him. He was a Samaritan.

17.verse: ‘There were ten of you healed, weren’t there?’ responded Jesus. ‘Where are the nine?

18.verse: Is it really the case that the only one who had the decency to give God the glory was this foreigner?

19.verse: ‘Get up, and be on your way,’ he said to him. ‘Your faith has saved you.’

20.verse: The Coming of the Kingdom - The Pharisees asked Jesus when the kingdom of God was coming. ‘God’s kingdom’, replied Jesus, ‘isn’t the sort of thing you can watch for and see coming.

21.verse: People won’t say “Look, here it is”, or “Look, over there!” No: God’s kingdom is within your grasp.’

22.verse: Then Jesus said to the disciples, ‘The days are coming when you will long to see one of the days of the son of man, and you won’t see it.

23.verse: They will say to you, “Look, there!” or “Look, here!” Don’t go off or follow them.

24.verse: The son of man in his day will be like lightning that shines from one end of the sky to the other.

25.verse: But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.

26.verse: ‘What will it be like in the days of the son of man? It will be like the days of Noah.

27.verse: People were eating and drinking, they were getting married and giving wedding parties, until the day when Noah went into the ark – and that day the flood came and swept them all away.

28.verse: And it will be like the days of Lot. They were eating and drinking, they were buying and selling, they were planting and building.

29.verse: But on the day when Lot left Sodom, it rained fire and sulphur from the sky and they were all destroyed.

30.verse: That’s what it will be like on the day when the son of man is revealed.

31.verse: ‘On that day anyone up on the roof, with all their possessions in the house, shouldn’t go down to get them. Anyone out in the field shouldn’t go back to get anything.

32.verse: Remember Lot’s wife.

33.verse: If you try to save your life you’ll lose it, but anyone who loses it will keep it.

34.verse: ‘Let me tell you, in that night there will be two people sleeping side by side: one will be taken, and the other left behind.

35.verse: There will be two women working side by side grinding corn: one will be taken and the other left behind.’

36.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

37.verse: ‘Where will this be, master?’ they asked him. ‘Where the body is,’ replied Jesus, ‘there the vultures will gather.’

1.verse: The Parables of the Persistent Widow and the Tax-Collector - Jesus told them a parable, about how they should always pray and not give up.

2.verse: ‘There was once a judge in a certain town,’ he said, ‘who didn’t fear God, and didn’t have any respect for people.

3.verse: There was a widow in that town, and she came to him and said, “Judge my case! Vindicate me against my enemy!”

4.verse: ‘For a long time he refused. But, in the end, he said to himself, “It’s true that I don’t fear God, and don’t have any respect for people.

5.verse: But because this widow is causing me a lot of trouble, I will put her case right and vindicate her, so that she doesn’t end up coming and giving me a black eye.”

6.verse: ‘Well,’ said the master, ‘did you hear what this unjust judge says?

7.verse: And don’t you think that God will see justice done for his chosen ones, who shout out to him day and night? Do you suppose he is deliberately delaying?

8.verse: Let me tell you, he will vindicate them very quickly. But – when the son of man comes, will he find faith on the earth?’

9.verse: He told this next parable against those who trusted in their own righteous standing and despised others.

10.verse: ‘Two men’, he said, ‘went up to the Temple to pray. One was a Pharisee, the other was a tax-collector.

11.verse: The Pharisee stood and prayed in this way to himself: “God, I thank you that I am not like the other people – greedy, unjust, immoral, or even like this tax-collector.

12.verse: I fast twice in the week; I give tithes of all that I get.”

13.verse: ‘But the tax-collector stood a long way off, and didn’t even want to raise his eyes to heaven. He beat his breast and said, “God, be merciful to me, sinner that I am.”

14.verse: Let me tell you, he was the one who went back to his house vindicated by God, not the other. Don’t you see? People who exalt themselves will be humbled, and people who humble themselves will be exalted.’

15.verse: The Rich Young Ruler - People were bringing even tiny babies to Jesus for him to touch them. When the disciples saw it, they forbade them sternly.

16.verse: But Jesus called them. ‘Let the children come to me,’ he said, ‘and don’t stop them! God’s kingdom belongs to the likes of these.

17.verse: I’m telling you the truth: anyone who doesn’t receive God’s kingdom like a child will never get into it.’

18.verse: There was a ruler who asked him, ‘Good teacher, what must I do to inherit the life of the age to come?’

19.verse: ‘Why call me good?’ said Jesus to him. ‘No one is good except God alone.

20.verse: You know the commandments: Don’t commit adultery, don’t kill, don’t steal, don’t swear falsely, honour your father and mother.’

21.verse: ‘I’ve kept them all’, he said, ‘since I was a boy.’

22.verse: When Jesus heard that, he said to him, ‘There’s just one thing you’re short of. Sell everything you own, and distribute it to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come and follow me.’

23.verse: When he heard that he turned very sad; he was extremely wealthy.

24.verse: Jesus saw that he had become sad, and said, ‘How hard it is for those with possessions to enter God’s kingdom!

25.verse: Yes: it’s easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter God’s kingdom.’

26.verse: The people who heard it said, ‘So who can be saved?’

27.verse: ‘What’s impossible for humans’, said Jesus, ‘is possible for God.’

28.verse: ‘Look here,’ said Peter, ‘we’ve left everything and followed you.’

29.verse: ‘I’m telling you the truth,’ said Jesus, ‘everyone who has left house or wife or brothers or parents or children, because of God’s kingdom,

30.verse: will receive far more in return in the present time – and in the age to come they will receive the life that belongs to that age.’

31.verse: Jesus Heals a Blind Beggar - Jesus took the Twelve aside. ‘Look,’ he said, ‘we’re going up to Jerusalem. Everything that’s written in the prophets about the son of man will be fulfilled.

32.verse: Yes: he will be handed over to the pagans; he’ll be mocked, abused and spat upon.

33.verse: They will beat him and kill him; and on the third day he’ll be raised.’

34.verse: They didn’t understand any of this. The word was hidden from them, and they didn’t know what he meant.

35.verse: As they were getting near Jericho there was a blind man sitting by the road, begging.

36.verse: When he heard a crowd passing through the town he asked what was going on.

37.verse: ‘Jesus of Nazareth is coming by,’ people said to him.

38.verse: So he shouted out, ‘Jesus – David’s son! Have pity on me!’

39.verse: The people who were at the front of the group firmly told him to be silent. But he yelled out all the more, ‘David’s son! Have pity on me!’

40.verse: Jesus stopped, and told them to bring the man to him. When he came up, he asked him,

41.verse: ‘What d’you want me to do for you?’ ‘Master,’ he said, ‘I want to see again.’

42.verse: ‘Then see again,’ said Jesus. ‘Your faith has saved you.’

43.verse: At once he received his sight again, and followed him, glorifying God. And when all the people saw it, they gave praise to God.

1.verse: The Calling of Zacchaeus - They went into Jericho and passed through.

2.verse: There was a man named Zacchaeus, a chief tax-collector, who was very rich.

3.verse: He was trying to see who Jesus was, but, being a small man, he couldn’t, because of the crowd.

4.verse: So he ran on ahead, along the route Jesus was going to take, and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him.

5.verse: When Jesus came to the place, he looked up. ‘Zacchaeus,’ he said to him, ‘hurry up and come down. I have to stay at your house today.’

6.verse: So he hurried up, came down, and welcomed him with joy.

7.verse: Everybody began to murmur when they saw it. ‘He’s gone in to spend time with a proper old sinner!’ they were saying.

8.verse: But Zacchaeus stood there and addressed the master. ‘Look, Master,’ he said, ‘I’m giving half my property to the poor. And if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I’m giving it back to them four times over.’

9.verse: ‘Today,’ said Jesus, ‘salvation has come to this house, because he too is a son of Abraham.

10.verse: You see, the son of man came to seek and to save the lost.’

11.verse: The King, the Servants and the Money - While people were listening to this, Jesus went on to tell a parable. They were, after all, getting close to Jerusalem, and they thought that the kingdom of God was going to appear at once.

12.verse: ‘There was once a nobleman,’ he said, ‘who went into a country far away to be given royal authority and then return.

13.verse: He summoned ten of his slaves and gave them ten silver coins. “Do business with these”, he said, “until I come back.”

14.verse: His subjects, though, hated him, and sent a delegation after him to say, “We don’t want this man to be our king.”

15.verse: ‘So it happened that when he received the kingship and came back again, he gave orders to summon these slaves who had received the money, so that he could find out how they had got on with their business efforts.

16.verse: The first came forward and said, “Master, your money has made ten times its value!”

17.verse: ‘ “Well done, you splendid servant!” he said. “You’ve been trustworthy with something small; now you can take command of ten cities.”

18.verse: ‘The second came and said, “Master, your money has made five times its value!”

19.verse: ‘ “You too – you can take charge of five cities.”

20.verse: ‘The other came and said, “Master, here is your money. I kept it wrapped in this handkerchief.

21.verse: You see, I was afraid of you, because you are a hard man: you profit where you made no investment, and you harvest what you didn’t sow.”

22.verse: ‘ “I’ll condemn you out of your own mouth, you wicked scoundrel of a servant!” he replied. “So: you knew that I was a hard man, profiting where I didn’t invest and harvesting where I didn’t sow?

23.verse: So why didn’t you put my money with the bankers? Then I’d have had the interest when I got back!”

24.verse: ‘ “Take the money from him,” he said to the bystanders, “and give it to the man who’s got it ten times over!”

25.verse: (“Master,” they said to him, “he’s got ten times that already!”)

26.verse: ‘Let me tell you: everyone who has will be given more; but if someone has nothing, even what he has will be taken away from him.

27.verse: But as for these enemies of mine, who didn’t want me to be king over them – bring them here and slaughter them in front of me.’

28.verse: The Triumphal Entry - With these words, Jesus went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.

29.verse: As they came close, as near as Bethany and Bethphage, at the place called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of the disciples on ahead.

30.verse: ‘Go into the village over there,’ he said, ‘and as you arrive you’ll find a colt tied up, one that nobody has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.

31.verse: If anyone says to you, “Why are you untying it?” you should say, “Because the master needs it”.’

32.verse: The two who were sent went off and found it just as Jesus had said to them.

33.verse: They untied the colt, and its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”

34.verse: “Because the master needs it,” they replied.

35.verse: They brought it to Jesus, threw their cloaks on the colt, and mounted Jesus on it.

36.verse: As he was going along, people kept spreading their cloaks on the road.

37.verse: When he came to the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began to celebrate and praise God at the tops of their voices for all the powerful deeds they had seen.

38.verse: ‘Welcome, welcome, welcome with a blessing,’ they sang. ‘Welcome to the king in the name of the Lord! ‘Peace in heaven, and glory on high!’

39.verse: Some of the Pharisees from the crowd said to Jesus, ‘Teacher, tell your disciples to stop that.’

40.verse: ‘Let me tell you,’ replied Jesus, ‘if they stayed silent, the stones would be shouting out!’

41.verse: Jesus Cleanses the Temple - When he came near and saw the city, he wept over it.

42.verse: ‘If only you’d known,’ he said, ‘on this day – even you! – what peace meant. But now it’s hidden, and you can’t see it.

43.verse: Yes, the days are coming upon you when your enemies will build up earthworks all round you, and encircle you, and squeeze you in from every direction.

44.verse: They will bring you crashing to the ground, you and your children within you. They won’t leave one single stone on another, because you didn’t know the moment when God was visiting you.’

45.verse: He went into the Temple and began to throw out the traders.

46.verse: ‘It’s written,’ he said, ‘my house shall be a house of prayer; but you’ve made it a brigands’ cave.’

47.verse: He was teaching every day in the Temple. But the chief priests, the scribes and the leading men of the people were trying to destroy him.

48.verse: They couldn’t find any way to do it, because all the people were hanging on his every word.

1.verse: The Question about Jesus’ Authority - On one of those days, while Jesus was teaching the people in the Temple, and announcing the good news, the chief priests and the scribes came up with the elders, and said to him,

2.verse: ‘Tell us: by what authority are you doing these things? Or who gave you this authority?’

3.verse: ‘I’ve got a question for you, too,’ said Jesus, ‘so tell me this:

4.verse: was John’s baptism from God, or was it merely human?’

5.verse: ‘If we say it was from God,’ they said among themselves, ‘he’ll say, So why didn’t you believe him?

6.verse: But if we say “merely human”, all the people will stone us, since they’re convinced that John was a prophet.’

7.verse: So they replied that they didn’t know where John and his baptism came from.

8.verse: ‘Very well, then,’ said Jesus. ‘Nor will I tell you by what authority I do these things.’

9.verse: The Parable of the Tenants - Jesus began to tell the people this parable. ‘There was a man who planted a vineyard, let it out to tenant farmers, and went abroad for a long while.

10.verse: When the time came, he sent a slave to the farmers to collect from them some of the produce of the vineyard. But the farmers beat him and sent him away empty-handed.

11.verse: He then sent a further slave, and they beat him, abused him, and sent him back empty-handed.

12.verse: Then he sent yet a third, and they beat him up and threw him out.

13.verse: ‘So the master of the vineyard said, “What shall I do? I’ll send my beloved son. They will certainly respect him!”

14.verse: But when the farmers saw him they said to each other, “This is the heir! Let’s kill him, and then the inheritance will belong to us!”

15.verse: And they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. ‘So what will the master of the vineyard do?

16.verse: He will come and wipe out those farmers, and give the vineyard to others.’ When they heard this, they said, ‘God forbid!’

17.verse: But Jesus looked round at them and said, ‘What then does it mean in the Bible when it says, The very stone the builders refused now for the corner’s top is used?

18.verse: ‘Everyone who falls on that stone will be smashed to smithereens; but if it falls on anyone, it will crush them.’

19.verse: The scribes and the chief priests tried to lay hands on him then and there. But they were afraid of the people, because they knew that Jesus had told this parable against them.

20.verse: On Paying Taxes to Caesar - So the authorities watched Jesus, and sent people to lie in wait for him. They pretended to be upright folk, but were trying to trap him in something he said, so that they could hand him over to the rule and authority of the governor.

21.verse: So they asked him this question. ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘we know that you speak and teach with integrity. You are completely impartial, and you teach God’s way and God’s truth.

22.verse: So: is it right for us to give tribute to Caesar, or not?’

23.verse: Jesus knew they were playing a trick.

24.verse: ‘Show me a tribute-coin,’ he said. ‘This image . . . and this inscription . . . who do they belong to?’ ‘Caesar,’ they said.

25.verse: ‘Well, then,’ replied Jesus, ‘you’d better give Caesar back what belongs to him! And give God back what belongs to him.’

26.verse: They couldn’t catch him in anything he said in front of the people. They were amazed at his answer, and had nothing more to say.

27.verse: Marriage and the Resurrection - Some of the Sadducees came to Jesus to put their question. (The Sadducees deny that there is any resurrection.)

28.verse: ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘Moses wrote for us that “If a man’s brother dies, leaving a widow but no children, the man should marry the widow and raise up a family for his brother.”

29.verse: Well, now: there were seven brothers; the eldest married a wife, and died without children.

30.verse: The second

31.verse: and the third married her, and then each of the seven, and they died without children.

32.verse: Finally the woman died as well.

33.verse: So, in the resurrection, whose wife will the woman be? The seven all had her as their wife.’

34.verse: ‘The children of this age’, replied Jesus, ‘marry and are given in marriage.

35.verse: But those who are counted worthy of a place in the age to come, and of the resurrection of the dead, don’t marry, and they are not given in marriage.

36.verse: This is because they can no longer die; they are the equivalent of angels. They are children of God, since they are children of the resurrection.

37.verse: ‘But when it comes to the dead being raised, Moses too declares it, in the passage about the burning bush, where scripture describes the Lord as “the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob”.

38.verse: God is God, not of the dead, but of the living. They are all alive to him.’

39.verse: ‘That was well said, teacher,’ commented some of the scribes,

40.verse: since they no longer dared ask him anything else.

41.verse: David’s Son and the Widow’s Mite - Jesus said to them, ‘How can people say that the Messiah is the son of David?

42.verse: David himself says, in the book of Psalms, The Lord says to the Lord of mine sit here at my right hand;

43.verse: until I place those foes of thine right underneath thy feet.

44.verse: ‘David, you see, calls him “Lord”; so how can he be his son?’

45.verse: As all the people listened to him, he said to the disciples,

46.verse: ‘Watch out for the scribes who like to go about in long robes, and enjoy being greeted in the market-place, sitting in the best seats in the synagogues, and taking the top table at dinners.

47.verse: They devour widows’ houses, and make long prayers without meaning them. Their judgment will be all the more severe.’

1.verse: He looked up and saw rich people putting their contributions into the Temple treasury.

2.verse: He also saw an impoverished widow putting in two tiny copper coins.

3.verse: ‘I’m telling you the truth,’ he said. ‘This poor widow has put in more than all of them.

4.verse: They all contributed into the collection out of their plenty, but she contributed out of her poverty, and gave her whole livelihood.’

5.verse: Signs of the End - Some people were talking about the Temple, saying how wonderfully it was decorated, with its beautiful stones and dedicated gifts. ‘Yes,’ said Jesus;

6.verse: ‘but the days will come when everything you see will be torn down. Not one stone will be left standing on another.’

7.verse: ‘Teacher,’ they asked him, ‘when will these things happen? What will be the sign that it’s all about to take place?’

8.verse: ‘Watch out that nobody deceives you,’ said Jesus. ‘Yes: lots of people will come using my name, saying “I’m the one!” and “The time has come!” Don’t go following them.

9.verse: When you hear about wars and rebellions, don’t be alarmed. These things have to happen first, but the end won’t come at once.

10.verse: ‘One nation will rise against another,’ he went on, ‘and one kingdom against another.

11.verse: There will be huge earthquakes, famines and plagues in various places, terrifying omens, and great signs from heaven.

12.verse: ‘Before all this happens they will lay hands on you and persecute you. They will hand you over to the synagogues and prisons. They will drag you before kings and governors because of my name.

13.verse: That will become an opportunity for you to tell your story.

14.verse: So settle it in your hearts not to work out beforehand what tale to tell;

15.verse: I’ll give you a mouth and wisdom, which none of your opponents will be able to resist or contradict.

16.verse: ‘You will be betrayed by parents, brothers and sisters, relatives and friends, and they will kill some of you.

17.verse: You will be hated by everyone because of my name.

18.verse: But no hair of your head will be lost.

19.verse: The way to keep your lives is to be patient.’

20.verse: The Distress of Jerusalem Predicted - ‘But,’ continued Jesus, ‘when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then you will know that her time of desolation has arrived.

21.verse: Then people in Judaea should run off to the hills, people in Jerusalem itself should get out as fast as they can, and people in the countryside shouldn’t go back into the city.

22.verse: Those will be the days of severe judgment, which will fulfil all the biblical warnings.

23.verse: Woe betide pregnant women, and nursing mothers, in those days! There is going to be huge distress on the earth, and divine anger against this people.

24.verse: The hungry sword will eat them up; they will be taken off as prisoners to every nation; and Jerusalem will be trampled by the pagans, until the times of the pagans are done.

25.verse: ‘There will be signs in the sun, the moon and the stars. On earth the nations will be in distress and confusion because of the roaring and swelling of the sea and its waves.

26.verse: People will faint from fear, and from imagining all that’s going to happen to the world. The powers of the heavens will be shaken.

27.verse: Then they will see “the son of man coming on a cloud” with power and great majesty.

28.verse: When all these things start to happen, stand up and lift up your heads, because the time has come for you to be redeemed.’

29.verse: He told them this parable. ‘Look at the fig tree and all the trees.

30.verse: When they are well into leaf, you can see for yourselves and know that summer is upon you.

31.verse: In the same way, when you see all these things happening, you will know that God’s kingdom is upon you.

32.verse: I’m telling you the truth; this generation won’t be gone before all of this happens.

33.verse: Heaven and earth may disappear, but these words of mine won’t disappear.’

34.verse: Watching for the Son of Man - ‘So watch out for yourselves,’ said Jesus, ‘that your hearts may not grow heavy with dissipation and drunkenness and the cares of this life, so that that day comes upon you suddenly,

35.verse: like a trap. It will come, you see, on everyone who lives on the face of the earth.

36.verse: Keep awake at all times, praying that you may have strength to escape all these things that will happen, and to stand before the son of man.’

37.verse: Jesus was teaching in the Temple by day, but at night he went out and stayed in the place called the Mount of Olives.

38.verse: And from early morning all the people flocked to him in the Temple, to hear him.

1.verse: The Last Supper - The time came for the festival of unleavened bread, known as Passover.

2.verse: The chief priests and the scribes looked for a way to assassinate Jesus, a difficult task because of the crowds.

3.verse: The satan entered into Judas, whose surname was Iscariot, who was one of the company of the Twelve.

4.verse: He went and held a meeting with the chief priests and officers, to discuss how he might hand Jesus over.

5.verse: They were delighted, and promised to pay him.

6.verse: He agreed, and started to look for an opportunity to hand him over to them when the crowds weren’t around.

7.verse: The day of unleavened bread arrived, the day when people had to kill the Passover lamb.

8.verse: Jesus dispatched Peter and John. ‘Off you go,’ he said, ‘and get the Passover ready for us to eat.’

9.verse: ‘Where d’you want us to prepare it?’ they asked him.

10.verse: ‘Listen carefully,’ said Jesus. ‘As you go into the city a man will meet you carrying a jar of water. Follow him, and when he goes into a house, go after him.

11.verse: Then say to the householder there, “The teacher says, ‘Where is the living-room where I can eat the Passover with my disciples?’ ”

12.verse: And he will show you a large upstairs room, laid out and ready. Make the preparations there.’

13.verse: So they went and found it as he had said to them, and they prepared the Passover.

14.verse: When the time came, Jesus sat down at table, and the apostles with him.

15.verse: ‘I have been so much looking forward to eating this Passover with you before I have to suffer,’ he said to them.

16.verse: ‘For – let me tell you – I won’t eat it again until it’s fulfilled in the kingdom of God.’

17.verse: Then he took a cup, and gave thanks, and said, ‘Take this and share it among yourselves.

18.verse: Let me tell you, from now on I won’t drink from the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.’

19.verse: Then he took some bread. He gave thanks, broke it and gave it to them. ‘This is my body,’ he said, ‘which is given for you. Do this in memory of me.’

20.verse: So too, after supper, with the cup: ‘This cup’, he said, ‘is the new covenant, in my blood which is shed for you.

21.verse: ‘But look here! The hand of the one who will betray me is with me at this table.

22.verse: The son of man is indeed going, as it is marked out for him; but woe betide that man by whom he is betrayed!’

23.verse: They began to ask each other which of them was going to do this.

24.verse: Prediction of Peter’s Denial - A quarrel began among them: which of them was to be seen as the most important?

25.verse: ‘Pagan kings lord it over their subjects,’ said Jesus to them, ‘and people in power get themselves called “Benefactors”.

26.verse: That’s not how it’s to be with you. The most important among you ought to be like the youngest. The leader should be like the servant.

27.verse: After all, who is the more important, the one who sits at table or the one who waits on him? The one at table, obviously! But I am with you here like a servant.

28.verse: ‘You are the ones who have stuck it out with me through the trials I’ve had to endure.

29.verse: This is my bequest to you: the kingdom my father bequeathed to me!

30.verse: What does this mean? You will eat and drink at my table, in my kingdom, and you will sit on thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

31.verse: ‘Simon, Simon, listen to this. The satan demanded to have you. He wanted to shake you into bits like wheat.

32.verse: But I prayed for you; I prayed that you wouldn’t run out of faith. And, when you turn back again, you must give strength to your brothers.’

33.verse: ‘Master,’ replied Simon, ‘I’m ready to go with you to prison – or to death!’

34.verse: ‘Let me tell you, Peter,’ replied Jesus, ‘the cock won’t crow today before you have three times denied that you know me.’

35.verse: ‘When I sent you out,’ Jesus said to them, ‘without purse or bag or sandals, were you short of anything?’ ‘Nothing,’ they replied.

36.verse: ‘But now,’ he said, ‘anyone who has a purse should take it, and the same with a bag. And anyone who doesn’t have a sword should sell his cloak and buy one.

37.verse: Let me tell you this: when the Bible says, “He was reckoned with the lawless”, it must find its fulfilment in me. Yes; everything about me must reach its goal.’

38.verse: ‘Look, Master,’ they said, ‘we’ve got a couple of swords here.’ ‘That’s enough!’ he said to them.

39.verse: Jesus Is Arrested - So off they went. Jesus headed, as usual, for the Mount of Olives, and his disciples followed him.

40.verse: When he came to the place, he said to them, ‘Pray that you won’t come into the trial.’

41.verse: He then withdrew from them about a stone’s throw, and knelt down to pray.

42.verse: ‘Father,’ he said, ‘if you wish it – please take this cup away from me! But it must be your will, not mine.’

43.verse: An angel appeared to him from heaven, strengthening him.

44.verse: By now he was in agony, and he prayed very fervently. And his sweat became like clots of blood, falling on the ground.

45.verse: Then he got up from praying, and came to the disciples and found them asleep because of sorrow.

46.verse: ‘Why are you sleeping?’ he said to them. ‘Get up and pray, so that you won’t come into the trial.’

47.verse: While he was still speaking, a crowd appeared. The man named Judas, one of the Twelve, was leading them. He came towards Jesus to kiss him,

48.verse: but Jesus said to him, ‘Judas! Are you going to betray the son of man with a kiss?’

49.verse: Jesus’ followers saw what was about to happen. ‘Master!’ they said. ‘Shall we go in with the swords?’

50.verse: And one of them struck the high priest’s servant, and cut off his right ear.

51.verse: ‘Enough of that!’ said Jesus, and healed the ear with a touch.

52.verse: Then Jesus spoke to the chief priests, the Temple guardsmen, and the elders who had come after him. ‘Anyone would think I was a brigand,’ he said, ‘for you to come out with swords and clubs!

53.verse: Every day I’ve been in the Temple with you and you never laid hands on me. But your moment has come at last, and so has the power of darkness.’

54.verse: Peter Denies Jesus - So they arrested Jesus, took him off, and brought him into the high priest’s house. Peter followed at a distance.

55.verse: They lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat around it, and Peter sat in among them.

56.verse: A servant-girl saw him sitting by the fire. She stared hard at him. ‘This fellow was with him!’ she said.

57.verse: Peter denied it. ‘I don’t know him, woman,’ he said.

58.verse: After a little while another man saw him and said, ‘You’re one of them!’ ‘No, my friend, I’m not,’ replied Peter.

59.verse: After the space of about an hour, another man insisted, ‘It’s true! This man was with him; he’s a Galilean too!’

60.verse: ‘My good fellow,’ said Peter, ‘I don’t know what you’re talking about.’ And at once, while he was still speaking, the cock crowed.

61.verse: The master turned and looked at Peter, and Peter called to mind the words the master had spoken to him: ‘Before the cock crows, this very day, you will deny me three times.’

62.verse: And he went outside and wept bitterly.

63.verse: The men who were holding Jesus began to make fun of him and knock him about.

64.verse: They blindfolded him. ‘Prophesy!’ they told him. ‘Who is it that’s hitting you?’

65.verse: And they said many other scandalous things to him.

66.verse: When the day broke, the official assembly of the people, the chief priests and the scribes came together, and they took him off to their council.

67.verse: ‘If you are the Messiah,’ they said, ‘tell us!’ ‘If I tell you,’ he said to them, ‘you won’t believe me.

68.verse: And if I ask you a question, you won’t answer me.

69.verse: But from now on the son of man will be seated at the right hand of God’s power.’

70.verse: ‘So you’re the son of God, are you?’ they said. ‘You say that I am,’ he said to them.

71.verse: ‘Why do we need any more witnesses?’ they said. ‘We’ve heard it ourselves, from his own mouth!’

1.verse: Jesus Before Pilate and Herod - The whole crowd of them got up and took Jesus to Pilate.

2.verse: They began to accuse him. ‘We found this fellow’, they said, ‘deceiving our nation! He was forbidding people to give tribute to Caesar, and saying that he is the Messiah – a king!’

3.verse: So Pilate asked Jesus, ‘You are the king of the Jews?’ ‘You said it,’ replied Jesus.

4.verse: ‘I find no fault in this man,’ said Pilate to the chief priests and the crowds.

5.verse: But they became insistent. ‘He’s stirring up the people,’ they said, ‘teaching them throughout the whole of Judaea. He began in Galilee, and now he’s come here.’

6.verse: When Pilate heard that, he asked if the man was indeed a Galilean.

7.verse: When he learned that he was from Herod’s jurisdiction he sent him to Herod, who happened also to be in Jerusalem at that time.

8.verse: When Herod saw Jesus he was delighted. He had been wanting to see him for quite some time now, since he’d heard about him, and hoped to see him perform some sign or other.

9.verse: He questioned him this way and that, but Jesus gave no answer at all.

10.verse: The chief priests and the scribes stood by, accusing him vehemently.

11.verse: Herod and his soldiers treated Jesus with contempt; they ridiculed him by dressing him up in a splendid robe, and sent him back to Pilate.

12.verse: And so it happened, that very day, that Herod and Pilate became friends with each other. Up until then, they had been enemies.

13.verse: Pilate Pressured by the Crowds - So Pilate called the chief priests, the rulers and the people.

14.verse: ‘You brought this man before me,’ he said to them, ‘on the grounds that he was leading the people astray. Look here, then: I examined him in your presence and I found no evidence in him of the charges you’re bringing against him.

15.verse: Nor did Herod; he sent him back to me. Look: there is no sign that he’s done anything to deserve death.

16.verse: So I’m going to flog him and let him go.’

17.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

18.verse: ‘Take him away!’ they shouted out all together. ‘Release Barabbas for us!’

19.verse: (Barabbas had been thrown into prison because of an uprising that had taken place in the city, and for murder.)

20.verse: Pilate spoke to them again, with the intention of letting Jesus go,

21.verse: but they shouted back, ‘Crucify him! Crucify him!’

22.verse: ‘Why?’ he said for the third time. ‘What’s he done wrong? I can’t find anything he’s done that deserves death, so I’m going to beat him and let him go.’

23.verse: But they went on shouting out at the tops of their voices, demanding that he be crucified; and eventually their shouts won the day.

24.verse: Pilate gave his verdict that their request should be granted.

25.verse: He released the man they asked for, the one who’d been thrown into prison because of rebellion and murder, and gave Jesus over to their demands.

26.verse: As they led him away, they grabbed a man from Cyrene called Simon, who was coming in to the city from outside, and they forced him to carry the crossbeam behind Jesus.

27.verse: The Crucifixion - A great crowd of the people followed Jesus, including women who were mourning and wailing for him.

28.verse: Jesus turned and spoke to them. ‘Daughters of Jerusalem,’ he said, ‘don’t cry for me. Cry for yourselves instead! Cry for your children!

29.verse: Listen: the time is coming when you will say, “A blessing on the barren! A blessing on wombs that never bore children, and breasts that never nursed them!”

30.verse: At that time people will start to say to the mountains, “Fall on us”, and to the hills, “Cover us”!

31.verse: Yes: if this is what they do with the green tree, what will happen to the dry one?’

32.verse: Two other criminals were taken away with him to be executed.

33.verse: When they came to the place called The Skull, they crucified him there, with the criminals, one on his right and one on his left.

34.verse: ‘Father,’ said Jesus, ‘forgive them! They don’t know what they’re doing!’ They divided his clothes, casting lots for them.

35.verse: The people stood around watching. The rulers hurled abuse at him. ‘He rescued others,’ they said, ‘let him try rescuing himself, if he really is the Messiah, God’s chosen one!’

36.verse: The soldiers added their taunts, coming up and offering him cheap wine.

37.verse: ‘If you’re the king of the Jews,’ they said, ‘rescue yourself!’

38.verse: The charge was written above him: ‘This is the King of the Jews.’

39.verse: One of the bad characters who was hanging there began to insult him. ‘Aren’t you the Messiah?’ he said. ‘Rescue yourself – and us, too!’

40.verse: But the other one told him off. ‘Don’t you fear God?’ he said. ‘You’re sharing the same fate that he is!

41.verse: In our case it’s fair enough; we’re getting exactly what we asked for. But this fellow hasn’t done anything out of order.

42.verse: ‘Jesus,’ he went on, ‘remember me when you finally become king.’

43.verse: ‘I’m telling you the truth,’ replied Jesus, ‘you’ll be with me in paradise, this very day.’

44.verse: The Death and Burial of Jesus - By the time of the sixth hour, darkness came over all the land.

45.verse: The sunlight vanished until the ninth hour. The veil of the Temple was ripped down the middle.

46.verse: Then Jesus shouted out at the top of his voice, ‘Here’s my spirit, father! You can take care of it now!’ And with that he died.

47.verse: The centurion saw what happened, and praised God. ‘This fellow’, he said, ‘really was in the right.’

48.verse: All the crowds who had come together for the spectacle saw what happened, and they went away beating their breasts.

49.verse: Those who knew Jesus, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, remained at a distance and watched the scene.

50.verse: Now there was a man named Joseph, a member of the council. He was a good and righteous man,

51.verse: and had not given his consent to the court’s verdict or actions. He was from Arimathea, a town in Judaea, and he was longing for God’s kingdom.

52.verse: He approached Pilate and asked for Jesus’ body.

53.verse: He took it down, wrapped it in a shroud, and put it in a tomb hollowed out of the rock, where no one had ever been laid.

54.verse: It was the day of Preparation, and the sabbath was beginning.

55.verse: The women who had followed Jesus, the ones who had come with him from Galilee, saw the tomb and how the body was laid.

56.verse: Then they went back to prepare spices and ointments. On the sabbath they rested, as the commandment specified.

1.verse: The Resurrection - The women went to the tomb in the very early morning of the first day of the week, carrying the spices they had prepared.

2.verse: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb,

3.verse: and when they went in they didn’t find the body of the Lord Jesus.

4.verse: As they were at a loss what to make of it all, suddenly two men in shining clothes stood beside them.

5.verse: The women were terrified, and bowed their faces towards the ground. But the men said to them, ‘Why look for the living with the dead?

6.verse: He isn’t here – he’s been raised! Don’t you remember? While you were still in Galilee he told you that

7.verse: the son of man must be handed over into the hands of sinners, and be crucified, and rise again on the third day.’

8.verse: And they remembered his words.

9.verse: They went back, away from the tomb, and told all this to the eleven and all the others.

10.verse: It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, and Mary the mother of James, and the others with them. They said this to the apostles;

11.verse: and this message seemed to them just stupid, useless talk, and they didn’t believe them.

12.verse: Peter, though, got up and ran to the tomb. He stooped down and saw only the grave-clothes. He went back home, perplexed at what had happened.

13.verse: On the Road to Emmaus - That very day, two of them were going to a village called Emmaus, which lay about seven miles from Jerusalem.

14.verse: They were discussing with each other all the various things that had taken place.

15.verse: As they were discussing, and arguing with each other, Jesus himself approached and walked with them.

16.verse: Their eyes, though, were prevented from recognizing him.

17.verse: ‘You’re obviously having a very important discussion on your walk,’ he said; ‘what’s it all about?’ They stood still, a picture of gloom.

18.verse: Then one of them, Cleopas by name, answered him. ‘You must be the only person around Jerusalem’, he said, ‘who doesn’t know what’s been going on there these last few days.’

19.verse: ‘What things?’ he asked. ‘To do with Jesus of Nazareth,’ they said to him. ‘He was a prophet. He acted with power and he spoke with power, before God and all the people.

20.verse: Our chief priests and rulers handed him over to be condemned to death, and they crucified him.

21.verse: But we were hoping that he was going to redeem Israel! ‘And now, what with all this, it’s the third day since it happened.

22.verse: But some women from our group have astonished us. They went to his tomb very early this morning,

23.verse: and didn’t find his body. They came back saying they’d seen a vision of angels, who said he was alive.

24.verse: Some of the folk with us went off to the tomb and found it just as the women had said, but they didn’t see him.’

25.verse: ‘You are so senseless!’ he said to them. ‘So slow in your hearts to believe all the things the prophets said to you! Don’t you see?

26.verse: This is what had to happen: the Messiah had to suffer, and then come into his glory!’

27.verse: So he began with Moses, and with all the prophets, and explained to them the things about himself throughout the whole Bible.

28.verse: Jesus Revealed at Emmaus - They drew near to the village where they were heading. Jesus gave the impression that he was going further,

29.verse: but they urged him strongly not to. ‘Stay with us,’ they said. ‘It’s nearly evening; the day is almost gone.’ And he went in to stay with them.

30.verse: As he was sitting at table with them he took the bread and gave thanks. He broke it and gave it to them.

31.verse: Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they recognized him; and he vanished from their sight.

32.verse: Then they said to each other, ‘Do you remember how our hearts were burning inside us, as he talked to us on the road, as he opened up the Bible for us?’

33.verse: And they got up then and there and went back to Jerusalem. There they found the eleven, and the people with them, gathered together.

34.verse: They were saying, ‘The Lord really has been raised! He’s appeared to Simon!’

35.verse: Then they told what had happened on the road, and how he was known to them in the breaking of the bread.

36.verse: Jesus’ Promise and Ascension - As they were saying this, Jesus himself stood in the midst of them, and said, ‘Peace be with you.’

37.verse: They were terrified and alarmed, and thought they were seeing a ghost.

38.verse: ‘Why are you so disturbed?’ he said. ‘Why do these questionings come up in your hearts?

39.verse: Look at my hands and feet; it really is me, myself. Touch me and see! Ghosts don’t have flesh and bones like you can see I have.’

40.verse: With these words, he showed them his hands and feet.

41.verse: While they were still in disbelief and amazement from sheer joy, he said to them, ‘Have you got something here to eat?’

42.verse: They gave him a piece of baked fish,

43.verse: which he took and ate in front of them.

44.verse: Then he said to them, ‘This is what I was talking to you about when I was still with you. Everything written about me in the law of Moses, and in the prophets and the Psalms, had to be fulfilled.’

45.verse: Then he opened their minds to understand the Bible.

46.verse: ‘This is what is written,’ he said. ‘The Messiah must suffer and rise from the dead on the third day,

47.verse: and in his name repentance, for the forgiveness of sins, must be announced to all the nations, beginning from Jerusalem.

48.verse: You are the witnesses for all this.

49.verse: Now, look: I’m sending upon you what my father has promised. But stay in the city until you are clothed with power from on high.’

50.verse: Then he took them out as far as Bethany, and lifted up his hands and blessed them.

51.verse: As he was blessing them, he was separated from them and carried into heaven.

52.verse: They worshipped him, and went back to Jerusalem in great joy.

53.verse: They spent all their time in the Temple, praising God.
